bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to Thomas W. Cridler, October 3, 1899
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General
U.S. Third Assistant Secretary of State

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D NOV 6 '99 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: No. 36, Consular Series. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, Oct. 3, 1899.
Owen L. W. Smith To Hon. Thos. W. Cridler, Third Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Subject. Cape Coast Castle Consular Agency.
No. 36, Consular Series. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; Oct. 3, 1899.
Hon. Thos. W. Cridler, Third Assistant Secretary, of State. Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt Sept. 27, of your No. 22, "Consular," of Aug. 26, 1899. You desire an expression from me relative to the retention or discontinuation of the Cape Coast Castle Consulor Agency. In making such an expression, I have to say, that whereas the late George E. Eminsang Esq., the late Consular Agent, died April 17, 1898; before I assued the responsibilities of
of this Consulate General. I have not been in official correspondence with said Agency; and therefore, feel very reluctant to advise, in the matter.

While at said Agency, in Gebruary last, I was impressed, by the businessmen and others of reputation, of Elmina and Cape Coast Castle, to believe that it was all important that said Agency should be retained. Having no knowledge of the volume of business transmitted between the United States and the Gold Coast Colony. I used every possible means to obtain as full a report of the Commercial statistics, as possible, and transmitted same to the
the Department, as a basis upon which it could make up its conclusions, relative to the retention or discontinuation of said Consular Agency.

Since writing my No. 33, "Consular," of Aug. 1, 1899, I have heard from Fynn Egyr Asaam Esq., who seems to have so far recovered his health as to think himself able to discharge the responsibilities of said Consular Agency, if appointed. I have, therefore, this day, forwarded to him, for execution and return to this Consulate General, a blank copy of "Application for Office." Form No. 205.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith; M. R. & C. General.
